A jewelry company uses a machine to apply a coating of gold on a certain style of necklace. The amount of gold applied to a necklace is approximately normally distributed. When the machine is working properly, the amount of gold applied to a necklace has a mean of <math alttext="300" overflow="scroll"><mn>300</mn></math> milligrams (<math alttext="m g" overflow="scroll"><mtext>mg</mtext></math>) and standard deviation of <math alttext="5 milligrams" overflow="scroll"> <mn>5</mn> <mo> </mo> <mtext>mg</mtext> </math>. (a) A necklace is randomly selected from the necklaces produced by the machine. Assuming that the machine is working properly, calculate the probability that the amount of gold applied to the necklace is between <math alttext="296 milligrams" overflow="scroll"><mn>296</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math> and <math alttext="304 milligrams" overflow="scroll"><mn>304</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math>.

The jewelry company wants to make sure the machine is working properly. Each day, Cleo, a statistician at the jewelry company, will take a random sample of the necklaces produced that day. Each selected necklace will be melted down and the amount of the gold applied to that necklace will be determined. Because a necklace must be destroyed to determine the amount of gold that was applied, Cleo will use random samples of size <math alttext="n equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> necklaces.Cleo starts by considering the mean amount of gold being applied to the necklaces. After Cleo takes a random sample of <math alttext="n equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> necklaces, she computes the sample mean amount of gold applied to the two necklaces.(b) Suppose the machine is working properly with a population mean amount of gold being applied of <math alttext="300 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>300</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math> and a population standard deviation of <math alttext="5 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math>.(i) Calculate the probability that the sample mean amount of gold applied to a random sample of <math alttext="n equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> necklaces will be greater than <math alttext="303 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>303</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math>.

(ii) Suppose Cleo took a random sample of <math alttext="n equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> necklaces that resulted in a sample mean amount of gold applied of <math alttext="303 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>303</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math>. Would that result indicate that the population mean amount of gold being applied by the machine is different from <math alttext="300 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>300</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math> ? Justify your answer without performing an inference procedure.

Now, Cleo will consider the variation in the amount of gold the machine applies to the necklaces. Because of the small sample size, <math alttext="n equals 2" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, Cleo will use the sample range of the data for the two randomly selected necklaces, rather than the sample standard deviation. Cleo will investigate the behavior of the range for samples of size <math alttext="n equals 2" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. She will simulate the sampling distribution of the range of the amount of gold applied to two randomly sampled necklaces. Cleo generates <math alttext="100,000" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mtext>,</mtext><mn>000</mn></math> random samples of size <math alttext="n equals 2" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> independent values from a normal distribution with mean <math alttext="mu equals 300" overflow="scroll"><mi>μ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>300</mn></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 5" overflow="scroll"><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. The range is calculated for the two observations in each sample. The simulated sampling distribution of the range is shown in Graph <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math>. This process is repeated using <math alttext="sigma equals 8" overflow="scroll"><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, as shown in Graph <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math>, and again using <math alttext="sigma equals 12" overflow="scroll"><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math>, as shown in Graph <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mtext>III</mtext></math>. (c) Use the information in the graphs to complete the following. (i) Describe the sampling distribution of the sample range for random samples of size <math alttext="n equals 2 " overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> from a normal distribution with standard deviation <math alttext="sigma equals 5" overflow="scroll"><mi>σ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>, as shown in Graph <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math>.

(ii) Describe how the sampling distribution of the sample range for samples of size <math alttext="n equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math> changes as the value of the population standard deviation <math alttext="sigma" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>σ</mi></math> increases.

Recall that Cleo needs to consider both the mean and standard deviation of the amount of gold applied to necklaces to determine whether the machine is working properly. Suppose that one month later, Cleo is again checking the machine to make sure it is working properly. Cleo takes a random sample of <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> necklaces and calculates the sample mean amount of gold applied as <math alttext="303 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>303</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math> and the sample range as <math alttext="10 milligrams " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math>.(d) Recall that the machine is working properly if the amount of gold applied to the necklaces has a mean of <math alttext="300 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>300</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math> and standard deviation of <math alttext="5 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math>.(i) Consider Cleo’s range of <math alttext="10 milligrams " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math> from the sample of size <math alttext="n equals 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>. If the machine is working properly with a standard deviation of <math alttext="5 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math>, is a sample range of <math alttext="10 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math> unusual? Justify your answer.

(ii) Do Cleo’s sample mean of <math alttext="303 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>303</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math> and range of <math alttext="10 milligrams" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mo> </mo><mtext>mg</mtext></math> indicate that the machine is not working properly? Explain your answer.
